intro: Chamaesyce geyeri var. wheeleriana, commonly known as Wheeler's sandmat, is a low-growing annual plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Portulacaceae and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. Its leaves are typically arranged in a rosette pattern, helping to conserve water in its native habitat. It is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance and ornamental appearance.
